name: Janssen Project
description: A low-code digital identity platform for workforce, consumer and citizen identity platform based on open standards like OAuth, OpenID, FIDO and SCIM.

sdgs.relevance: Governments are implementing digital identity to increase access to services using the Web and mobile applications. Effective registration, authentication and account recovery are critical identity journeys to rollout at scale. Both the public and private sector needs digital identity infrastrcture to effectively organize, and in fact to build the digital societies of the future.

openlicenses.openLicenseEvidenceURLs:
https://github.com/JanssenProject/jans/blob/main/LICENSE

Apache 2.0 is the preferred open source license of the Linux Foundation.

clearOwnership.clearOwnershipURL:
https://github.com/JanssenProject/jans/blob/main/docs/governance/charter.md

The "Janssen Project" name and logo are also Linux Foundation trademarks.

documentation: https://docs.jans.io is the official versioned documentation, although the Github repo itself (https://jans.io) has additional details.

NonPII.nonPIIAccessMechanism: As an open source project, there is PII in the Github site, for example pull requests, discussions, and wikis all contain references to Github usernames. The Janssen Project software itself does not "call home" with an kind of data.

openStandards: Janssen Project has submitted its "Certified OpenID Provider" certification to the OpenID Foundation:. See the published results at: https://openid.net/certification/  Furthmore
the Janssen Project also passes the OpenID Provider self certification suite for the profiles: Financial-grade API (FAPI) 1.0

and FAPI Client Initiated Backchannel Authentication.

The software also implements several other standards

Kantara UMA 2.0 and many OAuth 2.0 RFCs.  

The Janssen Project authors a domain specific language ("DSL") called Agama

along with a related data standards for packaging an Agama projects into an archive file. Agama enables developers to quickly define a web-based identity journey.  The Janssen Project is evangelizing the use of Agama at other digital identity projects
to enable portability across implementations of OpenID Connect providers.
bestPractices:
You can see our best practices here:

https://bestpractices.coreinfrastructure.org/en/projects/4353

dataPrivacySecurity.collectsPII: PII data is NOT collected NOT stored and NOT distributed.

userContent.contentManagement: Content is NOT collected NOT stored and NOT distributed.

otherDeploymentOrganisations: Idemia and Sensedia use the Janssen Project as the OpenID Provider for one or more of their products.

privacy.privacyCompliance: The project itself is just publishing software source code, binaries and using Github to faciliate collaboration with developers and the community.
privacy.privacyComplianceURL:
You can see all the Janssen goverance docs here: https://github.com/JanssenProject/jans/tree/main/docs/governance

Also, Github itself is publishes it's privacy policies here:
